content: Thunderbird does not have a function to import mbox files, so please be specific on the steps you are taking. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content:
Import from Apple Mail never really worked except in very old Thunderbird versions. This is still true for actual Thunderbird versions and my Mail.app version 16.0 running on macOS Monterey.

But there is a workaround: In Mail.app select a folder, e.g. an Inbox folder, R-click and choose "Export Mailbox". This will open a Finder window in which you'll choose the destination folder, e.g the Desktop.. The result of an Inbox export will be a folder INBOX.mbox (or Sent.mbox for a Sent export) on your Desktop. If you open INBOX.mbox with a double-click you'll see two files (see image): a file named mbox which is a text file containing the Inbox messages (similar to Thunderbird mbox files), and a table_of_contents file which is somewhat similar to an index file.

You can import those mbox files in Thunderbird with the add-on ImportExportTools NG or manually. I prefer the manual method: open the Thunderbird profile folder and quit TB, go to .../Mail/Local Folders/ and drag & drop the mbox file from your Desktop in Local Folders. When you restart TB you'll see a folder "mbox" in your Local Folders which you can rename as you like. To do this in a more efficient manner: you export several (or even all) of your mailboxes from Mail.app one after the other and rename the mbox files at once as you like, for instance Inbox-1, Inbox-2, ... Sent-1, Sent-2, Drafts-1, :.... etc. Then you open the profile folder via Users/username/ Library/Profiles/xxxxxxxx.default-relase/Mail/Local Folders/, drag & drop all those exported and renamed mbox files in Local Folders and restart TB where you can reorganise your imported Mail.app mailboxes

Accessing the Hidden User Library (macOS) https://support.native-instruments.com/hc/en-us/articles/360020012418-Accessing-the-Hidden-User-Library-macOS

Export Mail.app mailboxes https://support.apple.com/bg-bg/guide/mail/mlhlp1030/mac

creator: fernand474

content:
I am starting to feel like a broken record on this. Does anyone read the user support documentation that says what happens, or is the concept that the folder just do not exist to hard to grasp. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-gmail#w_understanding-gmail-labels-and-thunderbird-folders

"All mail" email can be deleted either be changing what happens when a mail is deleted to just mark it as deleted (it will still appear in the user interface with a strikethrough for a while.) This is what Google document on their website as their preferred arrangement. I just don't like it.

See https://support.google.com/mail/answer/78892?hl=en#zippy=%2Cthunderbird

Server settings tab

  • Check "Check for new messages at startup."
  • Check "Check for new messages every 10 minutes."
  • Next to "When I delete a message," select Just mark it as deleted.
  • Uncheck "Clean up ('Expunge') Inbox on Exit."
  • Uncheck "Empty Trash on Exit."

Copies & Folders tab

  • In the "When sending message, automatically" section, uncheck "Place a copy in."
  • In the "Drafts and Templates" section for "Keep message drafts in," select Other and then Your Gmail address and then [Gmail] and then Drafts.

Junk Settings tab

  • Uncheck "Enable adaptive junk mail controls for this account."


Or

Hold the shift key and press the delete key. That shortcut deletes directly and does not place a copy in the trash/deleted folder (which incidentally results in that email being restored to the all mail folder because that is where google stores ALL MAIL as they have no folders on their web site. Despite what appears to be folders in their webmail they are populated on the fly by google search using labels on the email in the all mail folder.

creator: mozilla767

content:
mozilla767 said
The problem the popup to refers is always a problem with the folder where the email should be moved to. I will take a screenshot the next time that such a popup occurs.

Good idea.

Make sure you do not have an antivirus scanning within the Thunderbird profile folder. Many issues with apparent corruption are caused by the file contention that their scanning invokes. The contention issue come as a function of how slow the antivirus scanning is, the size of the files on disk and the frequency they are opened.

In the case of say three consecutive emails being filtered to the same folder, Thunderbird may open and close the underlying file three times, not once as it did in years past. Each email action is now a discrete function because there used to be loads of IMAP timeouts happening because again of scanning delaying the IMAP sync. Now the issue has moved to the local folders because there does not appear to be any end to the number of times antivirus products will scan the same thing, let alone in a few second windows. ince on the wire downloading it, again on the wire sending the seen or read flag back to the serve, in memory once it arrives and again when Thunderbird commits the mail to disk. And that is for a normal text email add another delay while it decodes any attachments from the text based MIME and forms them back into their original binary format and scans those separately. If I sound like I am down on antivirus products you would be right.

Could it be those problem folders be your three largest frequently used folders?

The only ones greater than 1Gb in size for instance. Right click them, select properties and check the actual size on disk.

content:
As additional information, here is the my Mailfence chat conversation with a non-human:

Based on the information from the knowledge base, here are some troubleshooting steps and additional details for configuring Thunderbird with your Mailfence account: Detailed Configuration Steps: 

   Open Thunderbird and go to File -> New.    Click on Existing Mail Account.    Enter your:        Display Name        Email Address (your full Mailfence email)        Password    Click Done.

Important Points: 

   Only your primary email address or username can be used for authentication.    If you're using a custom domain-based address, ensure you've set up auto-configuration for your domain.

Manual Configuration Settings:

If the automatic configuration doesn't work, manually configure these settings: Incoming Server (IMAP): 

   Server Name: imap.mailfence.com    Port: 993    Connection Security: SSL/TLS    Authentication Method: Normal Password

Outgoing Server (SMTP): 

   Server Name: smtp.mailfence.com    Port: 465    Connection Security: SSL/TLS    Authentication Method: Normal Password    Username: Your full email address

Additional Troubleshooting Tips: 

   Check your account's connection history if you encounter errors to see why a connection attempt failed.    Verify settings in your Mailfence account under Settings -> Account -> My connection settings.    Ensure your subscription plan supports IMAP/SMTP access (Entry, Pro, or Ultra plans).    Make sureRemember password is checked during setup.

If these steps don't resolve the issue, consider checking: 

   Your firewall or antivirus settings    Whether your internet service provider blocks these ports    If two-factor authentication might be interfering with the connection

Would you like me to help you with any specific error messages you're receiving during the configuration process?

Yes. Unable to login a server. Probably wrong configuration, username, or password Done

Done!

I understand you're getting an "Unable to login to server" error, which typically indicates an issue with your credentials or server configuration. Let's address this systematically.

First, let's verify your account settings. According to the knowledge base, you should ensure that: 

   You're using your full email address as both the username and email address field in Thunderbird    Your password is entered correctly (case-sensitive)    IMAP access is enabled in your account settings

Here's what I recommend checking: Account Verification Steps: 

   Log into your webmail account first to confirm your credentials are working    Go to Settings → Account → My connection settings to verify:        IMAP is enabled        Your password is correct        No IP restrictions are blocking your connection

Common Fixes for This Error: 

   Username Format: Use your complete email address (e.g., user@domain.com) as the username, not just the part before @    Server Names: Ensure there are no extra spaces in:        IMAP: imap.mailfence.com        SMTP: smtp.mailfence.com    Authentication Method: Select "Normal Password" in Thunderbird's authentication settings    Port Numbers: Double-check they're exactly:        IMAP: 993 (SSL/TLS)        SMTP: 465 (SSL/TLS)

If you're still experiencing issues after verifying these settings, it might be helpful to check if there have been any recent changes to your account or if there are any ongoing service interruptions.

Would you like me to help you troubleshoot any specific aspect of these settings?

content:
re : I already contribute to Mozilla as I use Firefox

Thanks for your continued support, but just in case you were not aware - Thunderbird has it's own donation as they are separate, it's not the same as the one for Mozilla Firefox.

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/donate/

re: not able to logon to server issue You need to make sure there is nothing causing a block.

Firewall: This might be the default installed on computer or it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed.

  • Access the Firewall
  • Set up the Thunderbird program as 'allowed', this is important to ensure nothing blocks Thunderbird.
  • Please confirm you have set this up.

VPN Please check you computer to see if a VPN has been enabled. Some computers provide a VPN and some Anti-Virus products also provide a VPN. I've come across some people who discovered a VPN was in fact enabled. Please double check for a VPN and switch it off because servers do not like a VPN because it hides your IP address, so server thinks you are a potential hacker and it just blocks access.

  • Please Confirm you have checked that there is no VPN operating.

re :I purchased access to Mailfence Do you mean you have got a standard mailfence.com email address which you intend to use OR do you mean you have got a custom domain email address in mailfence?

If custom domain then please read this info: https://kb.mailfence.com/kb/auto-configuration-custom-domain/

Have you purchased any of the following: Entry, Pro, and Ultra subscription plans? If yes, then you can use Thunderbird to acess mail.

Mailfence also say: Only the primary email address or username can be used for authentication when you want to use a third party email client eg: IMAP in Thunderbird. Are you actually using whatever is set up as the 'primary email address' ? https://kb.mailfence.com/kb/is-the-username-that-i-choose-will-become-my-mailfence-account-email-address/

If you encounter an error message, we suggest checking your account connections history connections history (need to logon to webmail to locate it) to check why a particular connection attempt failed.

https://kb.mailfence.com/kb/how-can-use-mailfence-messages-with-thunderbird-using-smtp-and-imap-pop/

creator: jeff_l

content: Well disabling virus scans on outgoing mail did work--once, but no more. But I was able to send a message when I paused my VPN. This is not an issue with my ISP. I need to request that Mozilla fix whatever is preventing messages from being sent with a VPN active. I don't think it should be necessary to give up my VPN connection when I'm on wifi.
creator: jeff_l

content:
jeff l said
Well disabling virus scans on outgoing mail did work--once, but no more. But I was able to send a message when I paused my VPN. This is not an issue with my ISP. I need to request that Mozilla fix whatever is preventing messages from being sent with a VPN active. I don't think it should be necessary to give up my VPN connection when I'm on wifi.

It is not a TB issue. Your email provider is blocking your sent messages because of the VPN.

Here is the proof:

"Outgoing server (SMTP) error. The server responded: resomta-h2p-555359.sys.comcast.net resomta-h2p-555359.sys.comcast.net ESMTP server not available (62240/216.183.125.238)." That error message is coming from you provider, not TB.

"My provider says the issue is not at their end because my server settings are correct." It doesn't matter. The VPN changes the IP you're sending from, and the provider is blocking that IP.
creator: siffemoz

content:
joaquin.oakland said
I don't find in the on-line documentation any method to--when composing the body of an e-mail message--start new line without starting a new paragraph.

Nor will you as commencing a new line is commencing a new paragraph.

What I want is in a sense the opposite of the non-breaking space. I have read that discussion.

Everything to do with computing text layout has its roots in the paper printing industry. Not the typewriter document creation process. there is a somewhat general discussion on the subject here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2046530/whats-the-opposite-of-a-nbsp

I am asking how to enter a break, without adding the space that is use between paragraphs.

Generally in the Thunderbird composer you would change the style used from paragraph to body text. Then there will be not space between your paragraphs. Microsoft have done an excellent job at deskilling folk with regard to the use of styles with their word processor products tailored to breaking with the tradition of defined styles for specific types of text. They are however still a very big part of HTML and those that are not familiar with them often struggle with email formatting because HTML is the markup language used in email. There is also a setting that allows you to set the use of body text as the default.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
re When I use IMAP/SMTP incoming/outgoing servers, sending message fails: it asks me to enter another password, but does not give me a prompt to enter it

It's helpful if you posted an image of the error. All password prompts usually occur because either you have not saved the password in Thunderbird OR the server is refusing the currently saved password.

You cannot alter or modify any password in Thunderbird. Passwords can only be created and modified/reset if you logon to your webmail account via a browser. Then you can update the stored password in Thunderbird to match the new password.

Some servers use the Normal Password - same one you use to access webmail account. Other server insist you have to create a secure app password sometimes called an app generated password that you use only in Thunderbird for that specific email address. There are also some servers that use OAuth tokens, so a normal password is only ever used the once when setting up token and thereafter server uses the token.

What servers are you talking about? Please post an image of your outgoing server settings.

Include this data:

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section

Then either copy all data and paste it into this support question. Do not leave out some of the data because there are cases when people have more than one using account using same server and this data will tell if that is the case, so we can check you are sending using the correct smtp. Or can post an image showing the data.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
UPDATED - Firewall This might be the default one on computer or it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus product you installed. Access the Firewall and make sure Thunderbird has been set up as an allowed program. Then you know it will not block anything.

  • Confirm you have set up Thundrebird as allowed program.

Password: This is the password you use to access mail in the webmail account accessed via a browser. Please logon to your webmail account now as it's vital to ensure you get access on the new computer as it may have different IP etc.

  • Confirm the password got you access to your webmail account

VPN: Please check the computer to see if a VPN has been enabled. Some Anti-Virus products now include VPN. Most servers do not like VPN as it hides your IP and server might think you are attempting to hack the account. Switch off any VPN.

  • Confirm - VPN not enabled.

Are you in the process of creating a new mail account ? Advise - disable the 'Account Hub' option - see image below

  • Settings > General
  • uncheck this checkbox: 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'

Now create mail account:

  • Menu app icon (3 lines) > New Account > Email
  • Enter name, email address, password
  • make sure the checkbox to remember password is selected.
  • Click on 'Continue'

Thunderbird should attempt to locate server settings.

By default Thunderbird usually looks for IMAP Check the settings are correct: IMAP:

  • server name: mail.centurylink.net
  • Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address

POP:

  • server name: pop.centurylink.net
  • Port: 995
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address

Outgoing Server SMTP:

  • server name: smtp.centurylink.net
  • Port: 587
  • Connection Security: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address

Click on 'Done'

Please report back on results.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
How about you start with some current accurate information. That way someone might be able to figure out what is happening in your instance. Thunderbird saves mail to the accounts designated sent folder by default. I have seen the odd instance where that goes wrong where the Thunderbird software and the server software are using different languages. But it is not a general issue. Who is the mail provider? Is the mail account IMAP, POP or EWS?

Is your account configured to actually save sent email in account settings > Copies and folder?

See below for some of the settings options.

Just a point of interest, I see you flag this topic as having something to do with Android, despite posting in the desktop forum. Is it Android? That is a completely different product that happens to share a name. The source code is not even on the same servers.
creator: MattAuSupport
